text:
Breathe. Breathe. Feel the air. Feel that wind on your face. Feel the ground, your feet lifting you, pushing you forward. Feel the lightning. Feel its power. Its electricity is pumping through your veins, crackling through you, traveling to every nerve in your body, like a shock. You are no longer you now. You are part of something greater. You are a part of the Speed Force. It is yours. Now, run.

Welcome to the Flash Family, Speedster

subcategories.name: Basic Benefits
subcategories.text:
The flashes and other speedsters (Kid Flash and Jesse Chambers) receive their power from an extra-dimensional energy known as the "Speed Force" Not everyone with superhuman speed draws from the Speed Force (Superman, for example, does not), but those empowered by it are amongst the fastest around. You have received this momentous gift, and it bestows upon you an already impressive set of abilities by default. 

The following 2 abilities are free.

options.label: Frictionless Aura
options.description: The Speed Force's most basic and necessary power grants a weak force field around you, protecting you from air resistance and friction heat with the ground, allowing you to run at triple digit speeds without shredding your skin or causing massive turbulence in your wake. This only extends up to wind speeds of a certain level and does nothing to block large solid or liquid matter, hence limiting you to below the speed of sound, as the sonic boom will liquefy your organs. Additionally, you cannot strike with too much speed as it will shatter your human fists against the target, nor can you perform superhuman feats of strength like lifting a full-grown man.

options.label: Super Speed
options.description: The big one. A universal power that all speedsters share, regardless of nature or origin. The speed force allows you to hyper-accelerate your bosy to superhuman speeds, allowing you to effortlessly dodge, parry, evade, and act with lightning quickness. You can complete basic tasks instantaneously and 'cruise' at 500 kph (300 mph) without effort, edging towards 900 kph (560 mph) if you push yourself. Note that going below the speed of sound also means that you are slower than explosions and bullets so keep that in mind.

subcategories.name: Costume
subcategories.text: Choose a costume — the first costume you pick is free; additional costume choices cost 1 Point each.

options.label: Costume Ring
options.description: A tiny ring crafted using advanced nanotech that can compress an entire costume inside. Simply thumb the small stud and the ring ejects the costume, which then automatically forms around yourself.

options.label: Vibrational Guise
options.description: You can vibrate rapidly to blur your facial features and voice, allowing you to act in public without a face covering mask. You can also use this to defeat facial recognition software, granting you near-complete anonymity despite the highly conspicuous nature of your powers.

options.label: Speed Force Costume
options.description: You can construct your costume out of pure Speed Force energy, allowing you to summon and dispel it at will. Plus, you can instantly repair any damage to it and no longer need to worry about finding situations where it is out of reach (such as the shower)

options.label: Quick Change
options.description: The most basic form, you have a simple and mundane costume you dry-clean occasionally. With your super-speed, you can change into and out of it instantly.

subcategories.name: Speed Stunts
subcategories.text: The speed force activates on instinct, so your applications rely on muscle memory. You do not think quickly enough to solve complex tasks or execute advanced applications without training.

options.label: Run up Walls
options.description: Like running on water, you can overcome the pool of gravity by stepping so rapidly on the wall that friction allows you to stick to it.

options.label: Run on Water
options.description: Moving quickly enough and stepping onto the water with sufficient force, you can run on water using surface tension.

options.label: Turbine
options.description: You can control your arms at incredible speeds, blowing objects back with a cone of air. You can also use the same ability to slow falls, either for yourself or others.

options.label: Vacuum
options.description: You cna run in a circle, creating a vortex that sucks all the air out of an area, suffocating targets inside or putting out fires.

options.label: Molescular Vibration
options.description: You can vibrate your molecules to pass through solid matter, allowing you to walk through thin walls and escape from any buildings. However, note that you should not stay in this form for too long as you can breathe while intangible, and will start to sink through the ground.

options.label: Whirlwind
options.description: You can spin rapidly in place, creating an omnidirectional whirlwind blast of air that knocks objects back.

options.label: Transfer Speed
options.description: You can create a "bubble" of speed, force energy, allow, allowing you to temporarily take others with you at superhuman speeds. Alternatively, you can use this to boost the speed of other speeds, allow you to achieve even greater feats.

options.label: Speed Strike
options.description: You can unleash a ferocious flurry of punches, striking nearby enemies instantly (or one enemy a hundred times)

options.label: Super Speed Flight
options.description: An extremely unorthodox application of the speed force, only available to certain individuals (notably the Quick family) you can fly (or zip around quickly though the air)

options.label: Vibrating Strike
options.description: Reverse-Flash has performed deadly penetrating attacks by vibrating his hands at super speed before rupturing a target organs. For obvious reasons, the good guys never use this move (but there's nothing stopping you)

subcategories.name: Redline Stunts
subcategories.text:
The speed force grants a speedster impressive baseline ability. However, that is not its full potential. Should you choose, you can draw ever increasing amounts of the Speed Force into reality, enhancing your abilities to impossible levels. At this point, you no longer bend the rules of physics, you break them altogether. To achieve these incredible feats without turning yourself and the entire planet into a smoking crater from the sheer amount of energy released, the speed force "phases" you out of reality, edging you out ever closer towards the point of no-return. Be careful, for overuse of these 'redline' abilities will cause you to fall into the speed force itself, disappearing from reality forever. 

All Redline perks cost 2 points

options.label: Hyper-Speed
options.description: You can accelerate beyond the speed of sound, up to 3,000,000 km/h or 1,800,000 mph, allowing you to run around the Earth in minutes.

options.label: Lightspeed Punch
options.description: You accelerate your fist to near-light speed, delivering a punch that can shatter mountains and vaporize just about anything it touches

options.label: Time Travel
options.description: A particularly powerful speedster, such as Reverse-Flash, can travel through time under their own power without the use of the Flash's Cosmic Treadmill. This incredibly dangerous stunt can cause massive ripple effects across the timeline, as well as certainly pulling you into the speed force. However, you could attempt what the Reverse-Flash did, and disassociate yourself form the timeline, existing outside of linear flow of cause-and-effect. Not particularly good for sanity, but certainly better than oblivion.

options.label: Leech Speed Force
options.description: You can leech the power of other speedsters, 'tainting' the speed force, and making it deadly to other speedsters, causing them damage when they try to run fast. A highly evil application of the speed force, only Reverse-Flash has used it so far.

subcategories.name: Equipment
subcategories.text: The Flash family hardly ever uses equipment in their everyday superheroing, but there is nothing stopping you from borrowing something.

options.label: Cosmic Treadmill
options.description: Speedsters cannot normally travel through time, not without falling into the speed force or through exceptional circumstance. The specifically designed cosmic treadmill significantly lowers the speed threshold for time, travel by carefully modulating the speed, force energy, the user creates, allowing (relatively) safe temporal jaunts. Additionally, this precise manipulation of speed allows you to perform a "partial" time jump, glimpsing into the past without going through and altering it: An incredibly useful feature that mitigate the risks of altering the space-time continuum

options.label: Cold Gun
options.description: Captain Cold's signature, accidentally created, cold gun. The most common application of this weapon, and the primary way cold is a threat to The Flash, is it ability to emit omni-directional blast of super cooling energy, slowing the speed of all the particles in the area and countering the effects of the speed force. for obvious reasons, this would make it rather difficult to use while traveling is super speed. Alternatively, the gun can fire a beam of energy, freezing objects into icy blocks, turning the ground into a slick frictionless surface, or even creating icy shapes out of thin air, like icicles or giant ice cubes.

options.label: Cold's Suit
options.description: Captain Cold's thick insulated suit. Its material grants immunity to cold and even basic protection against blunt force trauma and projectiles.

options.label: Fireproof Suit
options.description: Heat Wave's fireproof suit consists of advanced flame, retardant material, granting the user complete immunity to heat and fire. It's thick construction also provides a level of protection against damage.

options.label: Heat Gun
options.description: Heat Wave's gun is a surprisingly complex piece of machinery for its function. At its most basic, it can emit a "heat ray," spontaneously, combusting any material it hits. For a longer lasting burn, it holds a reserve of Nepal that it mixes in, creating a makeshift flamethrower like projector that can cause grievous damage.

options.label: Exploding Rubber Chicken
options.description: The Trickster's joke rubber chicken, hiding a pound of C4 inside. Detonates a short while after you squeeze it.

options.label: Combat Yo-Yo
options.description: The Trickster's yo-yo, weighted to use as a flail, with spikes that extend when you spend it at maximum speed.

options.label: Hard Candy Trap
options.description: The trickster's jar of hard candy that shatters upon impact, unleashing a super-sticky and super-strong gel that rapidly expands to cover a massive area, hardening in seconds to trap targets inside. Overly sweet and tends to attract ants, but still edible.

options.label: Air Walking Shoes
options.description: Shoes that allow the trickster to fly (somehow). As they emit no noise, this can allow you to move extremely stealthily.

options.label: Weather Wand
options.description: Weather Wizard's wand can control the weather to affect an entire city or direct a focused strike on an individual. Fortunately, Mardon uses his powers extremely carefully. You can summon a storm, blanket, and area with fog, call lightning bolts from the sky, generate, miniature, glaciers, and whip up hurrican-force winds. Additionally, you can generate a "solid" cloud underneath your feet, allow you to fly short distances

options.label: Weather-Proof Suit
options.description: Weather Wizard's suit consists of advanced nanotech materials, granting the user complete immunity to weather effects.

options.label: Mirror Costume
options.description: Mirror Master's costume hides a surprising amount of armor in its thin fabric-like material. Additionally, it can shift its properties to make the user transparent.

options.label: Mirror Gun
options.description: Sam Scudder discovered the properties of the mirror gun and experimented with it extensively, creating a bewildering number of effects, ranging from the illusory to the quite real. The gun can create holo-duplicates of objects, confound peoples site with a bright flash, focus light destructively into a laser, and, most impressively, turn any reflective surface into a portal to the mirror dimension, allowing the user to teleport through reflective surfaces.

options.label: Trick Boomerangs
options.description: A cache of Captain Boomerang's boomerangs, which have extraordinary properties. Aside form standard weighted boomerangs to knock out targets, this box has BOOMerangs that can emit blinding light, Smokerangs that emit a cloud of smoke, aciderangs that spray a corrosive acid, electrorangs that stun a target with electricity, and Razorangs that have precision-milled aerodynamic surfaces for striking distant targets.

options.label: "De-Evolution" Ray
options.description: A bulky and complex device often used by Gorilla Grodd in his quest for world domination, the "De-Evolution" ray causes the victim to become increasingly dominated by ape like impulses and transforms them into a gorilla overtime. The transformation is particularly permanent, but strong will people can grapple with the challenges of their gorilla nature and gradually revert.

options.label: Pied Pipe
options.description: Pied Piper's pipe can create music that causes those who hear it to fall into a trance-like state, receptive to his demands. Strong willpower can resist it, however. Alternatively, the pipe can simply fire off a powerful sonic blast to knock targets down or create complex noises to trick targets.

options.label: Blaster Pistol
options.description: Future tech-baed pistol that fires blasts of superheated plasma causing powerful detonations wherever it strikes.

options.label: Future Tech Rifle
options.description: Rifle modified with future tech that fires standard 5.56mm bullets as standard with an automatic rate and extended range. Also has a hidden tracer that constantly transmits its location, allowing you to track it. Finally, Plunder has attached a powerful under barrel laser to fire a devastating pinpoint accurate blast.

options.label: Trick Tops
options.description: The top's collection of trick tops, all with impressive effects. Among these are streamer tops that burst into a continuous cloud of binding streamers, a "darklight" top that he met an unusual "darklight" the blocks hall light from passing through, a blinding top that blinds targets with a flashbang, bola tops that clamp around a single target, electro tops that tazes a single target, flamethrower tops that explode into a continuous burning field of napalm, tear gas tops that explode into a cloud of tear gas, glue tops that explode into a pool of sticky glue, standard grenade tops that just explode, sound wave of tops that he met a continuous piercing shriek at a target, and tornado tops that generate a mini tornado to pick up and throw things around.

options.label: Cryptic Past
options.description: Your true history is well hidden, making it extraordinarily difficult to dig up information about you, and to expose your identity. Anyone except for the world's greatest detectives, such as Batman, can hope to figure out your past.

options.label: Wealthy Business Owner
options.description: You own your own multimillion dollar business, granting you a sizable and independent source of income to finance your superheroic ventures. While nowhere near the heavy hitters like Wayne Enterprises or LexCorp, your business is still invaluable in tackling corporate related crimes.

options.label: Renowned
options.description: Everyone loves you! From the local police to the town mayor to the average Joe on the street, people greet you with eager smiles and high-fives as you passed at 100 km/h. They even have a little exhibit dedicated to you in the Flash Museum.

options.label: Journalism
options.description: Turn on the song that says surprisingly common profession among superheroes, for one simple reason: you might be able to cross the country in an hour, but you sure as hell cannot see that far. By positioning yourself in the heart of information exchange, you can keep abreast of all the latest and greatest happenings, as well as giving yourself a convenient excuse for cross country trips on short notice.

options.label: Technical Knowledge
options.description: A large part of speedsters are also intelligent and practical inventors, boosting a healthy amount of knowledge on mechanical, electronic, and chemical sciences. With this, you can easily bring your own equipment or advise expert on how to best make something completely new.

options.label: Forensics
options.description: A surprisingly common pairing with super speed, a good knowledge on behavioral sciences, criminal profiling, and forensics allows you to make snap deductions when you enter a scene, hopefully exploiting your powers to their maximum potential.

options.label: Contacts
options.description: You have extensive and well formed contacts, allowing you to quickly gather information on subjects or make special requests normally difficult to find.

options.label: Ultimate Speed
options.description: You have achieved ultimate understanding of the speed force, allowing you to execute moves and maneuvers with practiced ease. Every week, you can tap into your speed, force knowledge to execute a speed stunt or red line you have not taken.

options.label: Lifeline
options.description: The speed force is a constant pull on any speech that uses its gifts. At any point of great stress or fatigue, the temptation is all to present to simply… give in... and fade away from reality. You encounter the dangerous nature of the speed force with a "lifeline," and earthly connection, giving sufficient reason to not yield to the temptation to vanish forever, holding onto what is real, just a little longer

options.label: Barry Allen
options.description:
Barry Allen developed a reputation for taking things slow, to the bemusement and occasional frustration of friends, family, and his fiancee, fast-acting journalist Iris West: Barry's proclivity for deliberation and detail, made an excellent forensic scientist for the Central City Police Department, however, known for his ability to crack difficult cases.

Barry was working late one night in his lab when a bolt of lightning crashed through the window, striking a shelf of chemicals. Bathed in those electrified chemicals, he gained the power of super speed! Inspired by his childhood hero: Jay Garrick, Barry created a unique crimson costume, able to compress down to fit into a attending compartment in a tiny ring he wore. He took on the name and mantle of the Flash, the fastest man alive! 

Barry has a reputation as a "straight" law and order type. He is intelligent, careful, and thoughtful, and living life in the (literal) "fast lane" give him an appreciation for the smaller things

options.label: Iris West
options.description: A go-getting reporter for the Central City Picture News, Iris West found herself dating the laidback, perpetually late police scientist Barry Allen. They eventually married, and Iris learned Barry was the Flash, because he talked in his sleep.

options.label: Jay Garrick
options.description:
As a college student in chemistry at Midwestern University, Jay Garrick accidentally exposed himself to the vapors of an unknown experiment. Inhaling those vapors granted him the power of super-speed. Donning a red shirt with a lightning bolt crest and his distinctive winged helmet, Jay began using his powers to fight crime as the Flash. 

He became a founding member of the Justice Society of America and married his college sweetheart, Joan Williams. Now, one of the 'elder statesmen' of the superhero set, Jay considers it his responsibility to guide and mentor younger heroes, to help make them better at what they do. 

Jay is known for his good nature, folksy charm, and knack for fatherly advice, making him a great mentor and role-model for younger heroes. He has an iron core of strength when it comes to doing the right thing and protecting the people he cares about.

options.label: Wally West
options.description:
Iris West's nephew Wallace "Wally" West was president of the Blue Valley chapter of the Official Flash Fan Club. He was less than thrilled by his Aunt Iris' fiance Barry Allen, until he found out that Barry, through his work with the police department, knew the Flash! Wally jump at the opportunity to meet his idol, and the Flash showed him how he got his super-speed. Then, lightning struck twice, spilling. The same mixture of chemical goes onto Wally West, and granting him super speed!

Wally adopted a costume like his mentor and became Kid Flash, the fastest boy alive. He eventually became a founding member of the Teen Titans, but left the team to attend college, where he eventually adopted the name and costume of The Flash, moving to Keystone City, across the river from Barry's Old Central City stomping grounds. There, he met reporter Linda Park and the two of them developed a romantic relationship, eventually married and having twins: Jai and Iris. 

Although humble about the idea of succeeding Barry as The Flash, Wally learned more about the origins of the speeders' powers than virtually anyone: He was the first to break the lightspeed barrier and pass into the Speed Force and return, anchored by his love for Linda. 

Wally began his career as an impulsive and brash young man whose powers matched his personality. He grew up to become a fun-loving hero always ready with a quip, but constantly concerned he was not living up to Barry Allen's legacy. Over the years, he has become more confident in his abilities and, more importantly, in his role as The Flash. Now, Wally is a capable, friendly man who is always willing to lend a hand.

options.label: Linda Park
options.description:
Television journalist, Linda Park started her relationship with Wally West on an adversarial note, pressing him for an interview over the property damage caused by one of his super battles. Eventually, they became friendly and began to date. Wally has acknowledge his love for Linda as the "lifeline" that keeps him connected to the world, allowing him to return from the speed force.

Linda and Wally married, and they have twin children: Iris and Jai. The "Tornado Twins" have inherited versions of their father's super-speed, Linda decided to leave her career in journalism to study paediatrics, allowing her to better deal with the unique challenges posed by her children's heritage.

options.label: Bart Allen
options.description:
Bart Allen was born in the 30th century, grandson to Barry Allen and genetic heir to his grandfather's super-speed. Unfortunately, Bart's growth was hyper-accelerated, and the only way to protect him from his own speed, was to put him in a virtual reality environment.

Bart finally got to live a real life when you traveled back in time to the 20th century to stop an impending apocalypse, where he learned to use his powers with the help of the speech of the time, training alongside the Flash and Max Mercury. Bart became a hero with the name to match: Impulse.

Joining other young heroes, Impulse formed a team called Young Justice who adventured together. After joining the Teen Titans, Bart Allen finally felt ready to embrace the heroic legacy of a new name: Kid Flash. 

Though he has endured severe injury in his time as a hero, Kid Flash most often runs with a smile on his face, thrilled to be racing to battle alongside his friends and family.

options.label: Jesse Quick
options.description:
The race to assume her father Johnny (Quick) Chambers' super-heroic mantle, Jesse Chambers yield to her mother Libby's concerns for her safety and opted instead for Meta-human studies at Gotham University. Once there, however, watching her father and his Justice Society of America cohorts firsthand inspired her to finally embrace Johnny's legacy as the costumed Jesse Quick. Sadly, tragedy filled stints with the Titans, the death of her father, and various personal problems soured her on super-heroics, to the point she welcomes losing her powers while defeating Zoom. 

Eventually, Jesse's marriage to Hourman (Rick Tyler) and reconciliation with Libby restored both her heroic commitment and meta-human abilities, inspiring her to resume her Jesse Quick guise and accept an invitation to join the Justice League of America. 

Marriage has made Jesse self-confident, happy, and obnoxiously romantic, as well as curbing her old workaholic tendencies.

options.label: Max Mercury
options.description:
In 1838, a US Cavalry scout tried but could not prevent a massacre of the Blackfoot tribe he had befriended. Before the Scout died, a shaman blessed him, granting, the man superhuman speed, so he might stop further blood chat. After he recovered, the scout used his powers to help others, becoming renowned as Ahwehota, the Windrunner. When Windrunner first experienced the call of the Speed Force, he resisted merging with it and as a result suddenly found himself thrust into the 1890s. He continued his heroic activities in that era as Whip Whirlwind until later brushes with the Speed Force catapulted him to 1940. 

Settling in Oakwood Park, he took a job as a circus acrobat and secretly battled evildoers as Quicksilver throughout the 1940s. As Quicksilver, he gained newfound allies in Johnny Quick and the original Flash and shared with htem his hard-earned knowledge of the Speed Force. In 1948, Quicksilver found himself thrust through time once again. He landed in present-day Keystone City. 

Now known as Max Mercury, he continues to mentor speedsters, most notably Bart Allen. Max's Zen outlook makes him quiet and patient, as well as a perfect teacher and mentor.

options.label: Solovar
options.description: King Solovar is one of the wisest and smartest citizens of Gorilla City: He is also its ruler. He has dedicated himself to peaceful coexistence with humankind, which he has proven to the heroes of Earth multiple times. He often stands against machinations of Gorilla Grodd when they focus on Gorilla City. The outside world sometimes calls upon Solovar for technical advice on rogue pieces of Gorilla City technology.

subcategories.name: The Rogues
subcategories.text:
The rogues are a collection of technologically armed villains who banded together for bigger criminal payoffs and mutual support against their common enemy: The Flash. Over the years, the Rogues have evolved from a unique criminal comaraderie and played poker or visited their costume tailor of choice, Paul Gambi, as often as they plan new heists. They have evolved a set of rules governing the use of deadly force and other aspects of criminal behavior, enforced with ruthless relish by their acknowledged leader: Captain Cold. Years have passed since the Rogues' debut and one thing seems  certain, so long as there are Flashes there will be rogues to challenge them. 

Each Rogue add +1 points to your total

options.label: Captain Cold
options.description:
In hopes of escaping his abusive father, Leonard Snart moved in with his grandfather. He often rode in his grandfather's cold-storage truck which triggered his love of the cold. When his grandfather died, Leonard refused to go back to his father. Having no job and no prospects, Snart became a petty criminal, planning a robbery with other hoods only for the Flash to bust him. With his nascent gang in prison, Snart vowed revenge. 

He built a handheld prototype weapon that would, in theory, slow the Flash. He broke into a cyclotron lab to refine and empower his prototype. A guard stumbled across his break in, surprising him, and he fired the new weapon. To his amazement, the device froze the guard in place. Declaring a successful experiment, Snart reinvented himself as Captain Cold. 

Captain Cold has fought most incarnates of the Flash over the years and has developed a special relationship with that legacy. Snart has returned to his criminal ways after multiple attempts to break away from his past. 

Captain Cold portrays himself as an ice-hearted criminal, but he cares deeply about his fellow Rogues and just wants to earn a dishonest buck. Leo is not a killer, he will go out of his way to immobilize rather than kill.

options.label: Heat Wave
options.description:
Mick Rory has been fascinated with fire since he was a child, but eventually killed his own parents when he set their family home aflame. He lived with his uncle, but Mick's obsession continued to engulf him. 

While watching the news one night, Mick saw a resport on the Rogues, a group of Flash villains, Mick decided to turn his pyromania into a life of crime. Creating a hand-held flamethrower and designing his own fire-resistant suit, Mick began calling himself Heat Wave. 

Heat Wave has committed crimes in Central City and fought multiple incarnations of the Flash, before eventually meeting Captain Cold and joining the Rogues. 

Mick is a barely controlled pyromaniac. His criminal ventures are meant to please his obsession more than line his pockets, but he has bouts of extreme guilt and regret when given chances to reflect on the damage his life has caused.

options.label: The Trickster
options.description:
A juvenile delinquent from a badly broken home, young Axel Walker attracted the attention of the mysterious villainess known as Blascksmith just after he dropped out of high school. Walker did not have any impressive skills or accomplishments to boast of, but Blacksmith recognized that his recklessness and burning hatred could make him a formidable criminal operative. She gave Walker gadgets and weapons she somehow got from James Jesse, the original Trickster d recruited him into her criminal syndicate known as the Network. 

After the Network collapsed, Flash's rogues Gallery reluctantly accepted Walker. 

Axel Walker is an adrenaline junkie and closet nihilist. He has never left particularly close to another human being, and he never found anything worth believing in. He tries to fill the void in his soul with mischief and mayhem. Walker is much more ferocious and bloodthirsty than the rest of the Flash's so-called Rogues, but he is desperate for their dubious fraternity to accept him, and this is the sole reason he has yet to kill anyone yet in his crimes.

options.label: Weather Wizard
options.description:
Mark Mardon was serving jail time for robbery when he escaped and fled to the observatory where his brother Clyde was working on an experimental weather-controlling wand, When Clyde called Central City police to turn him in, Mark panicked at the thought of returning to jail and accidentally killed his brother with the weather wand. This crime haunts Mark's conscience to this day. 

In a deluded attempt at honoring his brother's legacy, Mark used the weather wand to commit crimes as the Weather Wizard. He was among the original Rogues who tangled with Barry Allen, and Mardon pondered retiring from his life of crime. However, the Rogues came back together every time a new speedster assumed the mantle of the Flash. 

Weather Wizard is about as unpredictable as, well, the weather. Mark delights in using ihs powers for destruction regardless of the collateral damage to others, but his guilt over his brother's death continues to burden him. Likewise, despite having enough savvy to apply his brother's weather technology, he limits his powers and his crimes, incapable of visualizing destruction on a global scale.

options.label: Mirror Master
options.description:
Sam Scudder first discovered his 'powers' while performing menial work in prison, where he accidentally poured a unique chemical on a mirror. Intrigued by the strange properties the mirror developed, Scudder eventually discerned the different powers at his disposal, the first being the ability to create mirror diplicates of people so they could commit crimes in his stead. 

Scudder met the Flash countless times, as a member of the Rogues and other criminal groups, later retiring. 

The current Mirror Master is Evan McCullouch. The Scottish mercenary grew up in an orphanage and, after not making an honest living, became one of the best hit men in the country. His life turned around when he realized his latest hit had been his biological father. He was too late to contact his mother, for depression led her to commit suicide. McCullouch was ready for a change when an American consortium approached him, offering him the gear of the first Mirror Master to function as a black op hit man in the guise of a super villain. 

McCullouch is still free and abroad along with his fellow Rogues, struggling with a cocaine addiction. He is a toghened mercenary, pragmatic, and a bit at odds with himself. He does not regret his criminal ways, but he follows a strict code of honor that he actively enforces, and he has his priorities set very clearly; to the point of betraying a client (and seeking revenge) if his work harms innocents.

options.label: Captain Boomerang
options.description:
After he learned to throw the boomerang as a child, Harkness' mother sent him from Australia to live in America. He went to work performing boomerang tricks for a toy company unknowningly owned by his father but would steal from the crowds to help line his pockets until the Flash put a stop to his thievery. 

After collaborating with the Rogues for a time, Captain Boomerang joined the Suicide Squad and retired after finishing his prison sentence, 

Captain Boomerang tends to get on people's nerves, making it difficult for others to like him. He is elf-serving, blunt, and a childish jerk with a sense of a superiority complex towards everyone else, including his allies. He is, however, a patriotic Aussie.

options.label: The Top
options.description: While imprisoned, Roscone Dillon resolved to use his childhood love of toys to become a better crook. Dillon eventually mastered the ability to spin in place at high speeds and built an arsenal of gimmick namesake toys to use as the costumed criminal Top. He became a Rogue and played the second Flash for ears, until unexplained reaction to the Scarlet Speedster's powers caused Dillon to discover his ability to transfer his consciousnesses into vacant minds.

subcategories.name: Other Enemies
subcategories.text:
Miscellenois enemies that have plagued the Flash Family thorughout the years. They are generally more violent and deadly, having greater ambitions than petty robbery (and also likely insane).. So, choose wisely before taking them up as your enemies. 

Each enemy adds +2 points

options.label: Abra Kadabra
options.description: Citizen Abra hails from the 64th century Earth, a time in which advanced technology has erased the line between science and sorcery, and an oppressive regime has ground the remaining sense of wonder from people's lives. Abra's dream of becoming a stage magician made him an anarchronism, and a most unhappy one at that. He fled at the first opportunity, stealing a time machine bound for the 21st century, erasing his timeline in the process.

options.label: Gorilla Grodd
options.description:
Every society has its outcasts. For the peaceful simian civilization of Gorilla City. It is Grodd. 

When Grodd try to wrest control of Gorilla City, Solovar was able to mentally contact and warn the Flash, who defeated Grodd and worded his plan to extend his power over the entire world.

Since then, Grodd has been a sworn enemy of both Solovar and the Scarlet Speedster. He tried to regain control over Gorilla City on multiple occasions and used his "force of mind" powers against the Flash as well. Grodd's stated ambition has always been the subjugation of both humanity and the." elevation" out apes and other animals to their "rightful" place as rulers of the Earth, with himself as their undisputed leader, of course.

Grodd is supremely arrogant about the power of his evolved, intellect and force of powers, lowering his superiority over "primitive" humans. He still has a fierce animal side, however, and indulgence in sheer bloodlust from time to time.

 Grodd is weak in terms of his raw combat abilities: Although he has gorilla strength and speed, he is no match for truly super-strong opponents in direct hand-to-hand combat. Grodd prefers to use his formidable mental powers to deal with foes. 

These powers range from the telekinetic to telepathic, allowing Grodd to hurl objects with great power, read minds, or project his thoughts across a large area. With effort, Grodd can also directly control mind, and perform a devastating mental blast to melt a target brain.

options.label: Reverse Flash
options.description:
Eobard Thawne was born in the 25th century, a descendant of Malcolm Thawne, alias Cobalt Blue. Further details of Eobard's past (or future) stay extremely vague and even he claims to not remember a large part of it. All that's known is that he went as far as to duplicate the electrochemical accident that gave Barry his speed, then traveled back in time to meet Barry Allen. Thawne has a burning animosity towards Barry Allen and all he stands for.

The Reverse Flash plagued the Flash throughout his career. However, no matter how many times the Flash defeats him, Reverse-Flash has appeared repeatedly to menace his arch-foe, somehow traveling in time either from the future or the past, even existing multiple times in the present. This has let certain heroes to believe that Reverse-Flash has somehow managed to "disassociate" himself from the timeline, existing as an entity detach from the flow of cause and affect.

Reverse-Flash is a man who has based his entire life on destroying Barry Allen and all that he stands for. This makes the Reverse-Flash petty and vicious, willing to hurt or kill others just to get at his nemesis. 

Reverse-Flash tapped into the same Speed Force as the Flash's, giving him similar, super speed powers. He can match the Flash's speed and his super speed stunts and capabilities.

options.label: Zoom
options.description:
Hunter Zolomon began his obsession with the criminal mind the day he was leaving home for college. His father, secretly a murderer, killed Hunter's mother when she gave him up to the police, then died in a confrontation with them. Hunter studied psychology and criminology, determined to stop people like his father. He became a criminal profiler, specializing in costumed criminals. 

While working with the Keystone City Police Department, Zolomon became friends with Wally West (the Flash) and the two worked together on occasion. When the Flash refused to use his Cosmic Treadmill to alter history and prevent Zolomon's mother's death, he tried to steal it. The resulting explosion "derailed" Zolomon from ordinary time, allowing him to move at super-speed. 

With his newfound powers, Zolomon embarked on a campaign of vigilantism, fighting the criminal element of Keystone and Central City with brutality that shocked all. When Wally West moved to stop Zoom, he began to believe that Flash did not have the empathy to do what was necessary and use his powers to their fullest extent. Hence, he looked to "improve" heroes by bringing tragedy into their lives. 

Zoom's powers come from his unique disconnection with time, allowing him to move faster than everything around him, giving him the appearance of moving at superspeed. Unlike the Flashes and other speedsters, he does not draw upon the Speed Force. Among other things, this means he cannot duplicate certain stunts, such as vibrating his molecules at super-speed or traveling through time (it also makes him immune to attacks that target the Speed Force, such as Reverse-Flash's leech power)

options.label: Girder
options.description:
Tony Woondwand's outraged fellow steelworkers tossed him into a vat of molten metal. Unbeknownst to them, the vat held strange materials taken from STAR labs, and they transformed Tony into the living metal man known as Girder. 

Despite his clueless boorishness and rusting form, Girder's indestructible nature makes him an in-demand mercenary villain. More prominently, Blacksmith recruited him to be a part of her Rogues, though proved to be one of defeats at the Flash's hands.

options.label: Magenta
options.description:
Frances Kane joined the world of superheoes when she started dating Wally West. At the time he was known as Kid Flash and was a member of the Teen Titans.

It later became known that Frances had magnetic base powers. At the behest of Wally, Frances became a superhero in her own right using the codename Magenta. The strain and pressure of the superhero lifestyle caused the couple to split up and exacerbated Frances' growing mental illness. 

The ordinary identity of Frances Kane became overtaken by a darker, often homicidal, personality, calling herself Magenta. In her quest to destroy Wally West, Magenta joined forces with the Injustice League and Captain Cold's rogues. Over the years, Magenta targeted Wally West multiple times and eventually Frances discovered that using her magnetic powers would trigger her split personality.

Frances Kane had a split personality. Her original persona is that of a mousy, innocent woman. She later developed the Mangenta identity, a starkly malevolent personality. 

Magenta can control ferrous metals by creating and manipulating magnetic fields.

options.label: Murmur
options.description:
Dr. Michael Christian Amar is a surgeon turned serial killer. A respected doctor, Amar's insanity drove him to murder; he wanted to quiet the voices in his head. He terrorized Central City and Keystone City before the Flash finally captured him. Amar made 2 mistakes as a serial killer. First, he had a modus operandi, cutting out the tongues of his victims, which made it easy to connect a single criminal to his crimes. Second, he could not stop talking to himself and blurted out the details of his crimes when captured. 

Amar quickly became convicted of multiple murders and imprisoned. Due to his insanity, he had immunity from the death penality. However, he discovered that his abnormal body chemistry was immune to poison and disease when he gave himself a lethal injection and did not die. Later, Amar cut out his own tongue and sewed his lips shut to keep himself from talking (though he still murmurs to himself). With the help of the villain Blacksmith, Murmur created and released a virus that killed the prison guards and prisoners so he can escape .

Murmur is a homicidal maniac who enjoys killing: His personality muted by the fact that he cannot speak. 

Murmur has an abnormal body chemistry that makes him immune to diseases, poison, and other toxins, which enables him to use them without fear of poisoning himself. He is also an expert knife fighter.

options.label: The Pied Piper
options.description:
The wealthy spared no expense curing their son's deafness and indulged his resulting obsession with music. In time, Hartley's genius unlocked the secrets of sound and, having grown bored with idle wealth, he turned to crime as the Pied Piper. Despite his talents, the second Flash invariably defeated the Piper, even when he joined the Rogues. 

Entirely self-centered, Hartley is nonetheless a nonviolent sort (unless something threatens his friends or causes). However, he has quite a soft-spot for the poor and needy. 

Hartley's a genius in sonology yields devices capable of shattering barriers and causing tsunamis.

options.label: Plunder
options.description:
Plunder was one of the deadliest killers-for-hire. Using an accidental creation of Mirror Master, Plunder crafted weaponry based on future-tech he had gleamed. 

Quickly finding a place in Blacksmith's Rogues, Plunder supported her plans for months before his identity as Keystone City Police detective Jared Morillo became known. Eventually, the Flash defeated Plunder and the other assembled rogues.

options.label: Tar Pit
options.description:
Joey Monteleone was the far less successful brother of one of Keystone City's major drug kingpins. What made Joey unique was his ability to project his mind into inanimate objects, making his frequent imprisonments quite bearable. One one fateful day, his mind became trapped inside a huge mass of flaming hot tar, leaving his body comatose inside Iron Heights prison. 

It was all a lark to Joey and calling himself Tar Pit, he embarked on a career in super-villainy. Despite repeated defeats at the hands of the third Flash, Tar Pit continues a fast climb up the ranks of costumed crooks. In his brief career, he has already been apart of Blacksmith's Rogues and the Secret Society of Super-Villains.

options.label: Shade
options.description:
Richard Swift was an English gentlemen in the early Victorian period who involved himself in a mystical event of n unknown nature that resulted in his transformation into something not human. The experience cost him his memories, and the Shade began a period of world travel and adventure (as well as occasionally hiring out as a killer). During this time, he met interesting people and began acquiring his great fortune. 

From boredom, the Shade turned to crime as a diversion. He sparred repeatedly with The Flash (Jay Garrick) and later with Garrick's successor, Barry Allen. This was a game to Swift, who was debonair and restrained. He would play the villain, then retire in Opal City (which he had adopted as his home and where he never committed crimes) when he needed a break. 

Swift is jaded in his immortality. He is sophisticated, cosmopolitan, erudite, and occassioanlly a bit of a snob, as a Victorian living in a "less-civilized" age. He is not so much immoral as amoral, though he retains an unyielding sense of honor. 

The Shade is immortal and quite possibly one of the few beings in the DC Universe that cannot die. He possesses a mystical connection to the dimension of the Shadowlands and can tap into it to manipulate shadow stuff for a variety of effects, including creating large zones of darkness and phantasmagorical arsenal of attacking shapes. He is quite accomplished in the use of his powers and his variety of stunts highlight his abilities, with exotic uses that include highly precise energy absorption and time travel. Aside from his powers, the Shade is intelligent, highly educated and an experienced world traveler.

options.label: Johnny Quick
options.description:
Little is known about the Anti-universe's speedster, but he may be a counterpart to Wally West, the third Flash. Like Wally West, Johnny Quick is in his twenties and inherited the role from another speedster. This Johnny Quick gained his powers by ingesting a drug derived from the blood of the previous Johnny Quick, whom he murdered. Since then, he has switched to using a synthetic form of "speed juice" (supplied by the US Government) with similar effects. He is a drug addict and suffers from poor impulse control and reduced attention span as a result. When the speed juice wears off, Johnny Quick slows down to sub-normal levels mentally and physically, with even his speech becoming drawn out and laborious. 

An adrenaline junkie and thrill-seeker, Johnny Quick acts without thinking first. The Anti-Earth's fastest man alive is less fearless than senseless, throwing himself into battle at top-speed without regard for his own well-being or that of his allies. Johnny Quick's impulsiveness draws the ire of his teammates. His hyperactive antics particularly vex Owlman, who taunts and punishes him for foolishness. His bigotry angers Power Ring, who bristles at Johnny's references to his race. The other Syndicators treat his as a useful flunky, not to trust with matters that require much common sense. 

Johnny Quick has super-speed abilities like those of the Flash, though they come through artificial means. It is unknown whether he has a connection to the Speed Force (or whatever the equivalent is in the anti-universe) as do the normal speedsters.
